revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=February 2016}} {{Infobox military person |image= Royal Airforce Badge.png |name=George Innes |birth_date={{Birth date|1923|11|26|df=yes}} |death_date={{Death date and age|2015|1|11|1923|11|26|df=yes}} |placeofburial= |birth_place=[[Musselburgh]], [[East Lothian]] |death_place=[[Dorset]] |nickname= |birth_name=George Innes |allegiance={{flag|United Kingdom}} |branch={{air force|United Kingdom}} |serviceyears=1943-1978 |rank=[[Air Commodore]] |servicenumber=193292 |unit=[[Special Investigation Branch#Royal Air Force Police SIB|Special Investigation Branch]] |commands=[[RAF Police]] |battles=[[World War II]]
[[Cold War]] |battles_label= |awards=[[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] {{plainlist| }} |relations= }} Air Commodore '''George Innes''' [[CBE]] (26 November 1923 - 11 January 2015) was a [[Royal Air Force]] officer, former RAF Provost Marshal and head of [[RAF]] counter intelligence who helped expose a Soviet spy in 1968 and was security officer for the British nuclear tests conducted at [[Kiritimati|Christmas Island]].http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/11492443/Air-Commodore-George-Innes-obituary.html ==Early life== Innes was born on 26 November 1923 at [[Musselburgh]], [[East Lothian]] and educated at Crookston School in [[Scotland]].[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/11492443/Air-Commodore-George-Innes-obituary.html Telegraph Obituary - George Innes CBE MBIM] ==Wartime service== He was called up for service at the end of 1943 as [[Aircraftman]] 2nd class (service number 1570346) and became a student pilot, training at [[Weeton Barracks|RAF Weeton]] and on the [[Commonwealth Air Training Plan]] in [[South Africa]].[http://www.scotsman.com/news/obituaries/obituary-air-commodore-george-innes-cbe-1-3732544 The Scotsman - Obituary - George Innes] Commissioned as [[pilot officer]] on 31 March 1945,{{LondonGazette|issue=37124|supp=yes|startpage=3077|date=8 June 1945}} Innes gained his pilot's [[aircrew brevet]] wings just as hostilities ended in Europe. On 1 October 1945 he was promoted [[flying officer]].{{LondonGazette|issue=37333|supp=yes|startpage=5338|date=30 October 1945}} On discharge from wartime service he joined the [[City of Edinburgh Police|City of Edinburgh police force]], serving as a police constable until his application for a commission in the Provost and Security Branch of the [[Royal Air Force]].[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/11492443/Air-Commodore-George-Innes-obituary.html Telegraph Obituary - George Innes CBE MBIM] ==Royal Air Force career== [[File:Bhumbol and Sirikit.jpg|thumb|305px|[[Bhumibol Adulyadej]] and [[Sirikit]] after their wedding.]] ===Far East=== In January 1946 he was in command of the [[RAF Police]] in [[Bangkok]] following the assassination of King Ramas VIII [[Ananda Mahidol]]. Innes accomplished the safe extraction of the new King Ramas IX [[Bhumibol Adulyadej]] using an [[RAF]] transport aircraft before he could suffer a similar fate.[http://www.edinburghnews.scotsman.com/life-style/obituaries/obituary-george-innes-91-1-3733915 Edinburgh News Obituary - G Innes CBE] He served as an acting [[flying officer]]. Shortly afterwards the RAF moved out of Thailand and he set up the regional HQ of the [[Special Investigation Branch#Royal Air Force Police SIB|Special Investigation Branch]] of the [[RAF Police]] in Rangoon. Until 20 February 1947 Innes held the appointment of Assistant to the Provost Marshal,{{LondonGazette|issue=38338|supp=yes|startpage=3783|date=25 June 1948}} later proving himself successful in Hong Kong and Singapore. For some time he was in charge of training RAF police dogs at [[RAF Netheravon]], Wiltshire. On 7 May 1951 Innes was appointed an Assistant to the Provost Marshal.{{LondonGazette|issue=39445|supp=yes|startpage=453|date=18 January 1952}} On 13 March 1951 he was promoted to full [[Flying Officer]] on a short service commission,{{LondonGazette|issue=39209|supp=yes|startpage=2314|date=20 April 1951}} which was updated on 1 April 1952 to a permanent regular commission,{{LondonGazette|issue=39784|supp=yes|startpage=1093|date=20 February 1953}} and then on 1 January 1953 he was promoted [[flight lieutenant]].{{LondonGazette|issue=39739|supp=yes|startpage=56|date=30 December 1952}} ===Thermo nuclear Tests=== Innes specialised in criminal investigations and counterintelligence, and was appointed security officer for Task Force Grapple, participating in [[Operation Grapple]] – the British thermonuclear tests conducted at [[Kiritimati]], [[Christmas Island]] – in 1956.[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/11492443/Air-Commodore-George-Innes-obituary.html Telegraph Obituary - George Innes CBE MBIM] ===Counterintelligence=== [[File:CBEwithMilitaryRibbon.jpg|thumb|305px|Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] In 1963 Innes was one for two [[RAF]] officers appointed to supervise the creation of the RAF Security Directorate to review internal security. This followed a high-profile inquiry headed by [[Lord Denning MR|Lord Denning]] into the [[Portland Spy Ring]], which resulted in the conviction of five people who had been spying within the [[Royal Navy]] for the Soviets. On 1 January 1966 Innes was promoted [[squadron leader]].{{LondonGazette|issue=41915|supp=yes|startpage=70|date=29 December 1959}} In February 1968 [[MI5]] received a tip that an RAF serviceman was offering information to the Soviet [[GRU]] intelligence service and after initial case work was completed, in July the RAF became involved. As head of RAF counterintelligence, Innes led the hunt and identified [[Chief Technician]] Douglas Britten (born 31 October 1931, died Feb 1990), an RAF signals intelligence specialist serving at No. 399 Signals Unit at [[RAF Digby]] and also at a listening station in [[Cyprus]] which cooperated with [[Government Communications Headquarters]] (GCHQ).[http://www.scotsman.com/news/obituaries/obituary-air-commodore-george-innes-cbe-1-3732544 The Scotsman - Obituary - George Innes] Innes’s team arrested Britten on 13 September 1968.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=V-ZVcsl0h3EC&pg=PA41&lpg=PA41&dq=%22Douglas+britten%22&source=bl&ots=otI55BJVVB&sig=VArF9Ms5zXOOxL0NHwiARmx_Fp4&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjR2Yyb1YHKAhUBHx4KHY3SDXkQ6AEIUzAK#v=onepage&q=%22Douglas%20britten%22&f=false Encyclopaedia of Cold War Spies - Douglas Britten] Searches of Britten’s home and other locations yielded spying equipment including some supplied by the Soviet Intelligence Service. Britten confessed and stood trial at the [[Central Criminal Court]], receiving a sentence of 21 years imprisonment.[http://www.kissack.co.uk/index.php?page=britten-arrested-for-spying Kissack - Arrest of Britten][http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1968/11/05/page/44/article/british-airman-sentenced-as-spy-for-soviet Chicago Tribune 5 November 1968 - Britten sentenced]National Archives, London. Document PREM 13/2381 On 1 January 1974 Innes was promoted [[group captain]].{{LondonGazette|issue=46174|supp=yes|startpage=286|date=7 January 1974}} ===RAF Provost Marshal=== In 1976 Innes was appointed an [[Aide-de-camp#United Kingdom|ADC]] to the Queen, and on 27 February appointed RAF [[Provost marshal|Provost Marshal,]] the highest post within the [[RAF Police]],{{LondonGazette|issue=46889|supp=yes|startpage=6387|date=3 May 1976}} quickly being promoted to [[Air Commodore]] on 1 July 1976.{{LondonGazette|issue=46953|supp=yes|startpage=9292|date=5 July 1976}} Innes held the position until 13 May 1978.{{LondonGazette|issue=47545|supp=yes|startpage=6557|date=26 May 1978}} He retired on 1 July 1978.{{LondonGazette|issue=47609|supp=yes|startpage=9492|date=7 August 1978}} ==Honours and awards== * [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] - January 1978.{{LondonGazette|issue=47418|supp=yes|startpage=7|date=30 Dec 1977}} ==Later life== He became principal emergency planning officer responsible for home defence and responding to natural disasters for [[Strathclyde Regional Council]], and he later took up a similar job with the [[Greater London Council]]. Innes followed football and rugby, attending games at [[Murrayfield]] until shortly before his death, and was also a keen golfer. He married his wife Betty, a former [[Women's Auxiliary Air Force|WAAF]], in 1947. She and their son and daughter survived him. Innes died on 11 January 2015 in [[Dorset]] although his funeral was held in St. Michael's church at [[Inveresk]].[http://www.scotsman.com/news/obituaries/obituary-air-commodore-george-innes-cbe-1-3732544 The Scotsman - Obituary - George Innes][http://www.rafpa.com/2015_1.pdf RAF Police Association - Obituary G Innes] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Innes, George}} [[Category:1923 births]] [[Category:2015 deaths]] [[Category:Royal Air Force officers]] [[Category:People from Musselburgh]] [[Category:Commanders of the Order of the British Empire]] [[Category:Detectives and criminal investigators]] [[Category:Royal Air Force pilots of World War II]]
